intro: Acer tataricum subsp. aidzuense, commonly known as the Japanese maple or Aidzu maple, is a species native to Japan. It is a deciduous tree or shrub characterized by its distinctive palmate leaves that turn vibrant colors in autumn. The plant typically grows to a height of 3–6 meters and prefers well-drained, acidic soils. It is often cultivated for its ornamental value due to its attractive foliage and compact growth habit. The subspecies is closely related to other members of the Acer genus, sharing similar ecological and morphological traits.
